persons.name: Leucippus
persons.description: a pre-Socratic Greek philosopher. He is traditionally credited as the founder of atomism, which he developed with his student Democritus. Leucippus divided the world into two entities: atoms, indivisible particles that make up all things, and the void, the nothingness that exists between the atoms.

places.name: Mediterranean Sea
places.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

persons.name: EdmondHalley
persons.description: Astronomer and natural philosopher, who, using Newtonian mechanics, predicted the return of what became the eponymous comet. FRSL.

persons.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
persons.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

persons.name: JohnWoodward
persons.description: Natural philospher with an interest in geology. His collection of fossils and minerals is part of Cambridge University's Sedgwick Museum of Geology. FRSL.

places.name: Derby
places.description: Derby is an English city on the banks of the River Derwent in Derbyshire.

works.name: An Inquiry Into the Original State and Formation of the Earth
works.author: John Whitehurst

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: Torbern OlafBergman
persons.description: Swedish chemist and mineralogist. At some point Davy acquired a set of letters from Bergman to Franz Schwediaur written in the 1780s which are retained in the Royal Institution (RI MS HD/27/A). ForMemRSL.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: JohnWhitehurst
persons.description: a clockmaker and scientist who made significant early contributions to geology and was an influential member of the Lunar Society.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: JamesHutton
persons.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.
